list_definition.definition: (of soil, plants, humans and other animals) unable to produce crops, seeds, children or young.

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: A surgeon’s equipment must be absolutely sterile.

list_ex_of_english: In recording topography, the tendency has been to survey the earthworks in isolation, yielding aesthetic, yet largely sterile, sets of two-dimensional plans.
A work so conceived can have no emotional power; it is bound to be dull and sterile.
Specimens are extracted under clean and sterile conditions.
The uppermost flowers are usually light blue, small and sterile, whereas the flowers below are blackish blue with white recurved teeth.
Reproductive status was dichotomized for the analyses presented here; sterile trees lacked any reproductive structures while fertile trees had one or more reproductive structures.
This requirement causes controversy, since it does not recognize various sterile organisms as being alive.
The piece of jejunum was flushed with sterile saline, then further divided into 2 cm lengths.
Rather than attempting uniform area-wide, inundative releases of sterile males, it may be more cost-effective to preferentially target aggregated populations associated with livestock.
